title: where does _.where fit in?
body:
Going through the docs and a book and I can't figure out what _.where can do that _.filter cannot.

The "Lodash essentials" promotes _.where as 

> "The where() function is great for its concise syntax and intuitive application to collections. " 

which isn't really saying much.

In the doc examples _.where can be replaced with _.filter and still work the same.

Is there a reason _.where isn't just aliased to _.filter.  Is there a performance difference?  If there is a difference, I think it should be clarified in the docs and the example should reflect it.

title: Fix root detection of self and window in FF sandboxes
Make sure root is the global object. Fix lodash in Firefox extensions
body:
Lodash does not run within the content script of a Firefox Bootstraped extensions. Firefox add-on SDK extensions are not affected.

The basic problem is to get the correct `global` object.

Within the content script sandbox properties like `window` and `self` are available and refer to the current window/tab. Unfortunately `window` and `self` are not the global object inside the sandbox.

For example: 

``` js
window.Math === Math // false
self.Math === Math   // false
```

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3.10.0/lodash.js#L274

At this point `root` has a reference to the wrong object. A working solution can be found here: https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/master/modules/%24.js#L2

For more information and discussion, see: 

https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/pull/91
https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/issues/86

title: Processing a template that contains `${whatever}` throws an error
body:
This piece of code throws an error:

``` js
_.template('<%= foo %> ${bar}')({foo: 'foo'})
```

```
ReferenceError: bar is not defined
    at eval (lodash.templateSources[1]:9:10)
    at repl:1:35
    at REPLServer.defaultEval (repl.js:154:27)
    at bound (domain.js:254:14)
    at REPLServer.runBound [as eval] (domain.js:267:12)
    at REPLServer.<anonymous> (repl.js:308:12)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at REPLServer.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at REPLServer.Interface._onLine (readline.js:210:10)
    at REPLServer.Interface._line (readline.js:549:8)
```

I'm using the default `templateSettings`:

``` js
_.templateSettings
```

```
{ escape: /<%-([\s\S]+?)%>/g,
  evaluate: /<%([\s\S]+?)%>/g,
  interpolate: /<%=([\s\S]+?)%>/g,
  variable: '' }
```

So I'm not sure why lodash would try to replace `${bar}`. Am I missing something?

title: _.any executes more than is necessary
body:
I have a use case that involves a relatively expensive mapping process, but cheap checking with `_.any` at the end.  I figured I'd be able to avoid processing mapped items, since `any` will only need to process some subset of array values at the end, but no dice.  `any` forces the entire collection to be mapped.

For clarity, here's an example:

```
_(['a', 'b', 'c'])
  .map(function () { console.log('mapping'); })
  .any(function () { return true; });
```

In this (admittedly trivial) example, "mapping" prints out three times, while we can intuitively see that `any` is going to accept the first result, so we don't really need to process `map` for the second and third values.

Is what I'm imaging here possible, and desirable to lodash?

title: _.inRange behavior unexpected when end < start
body:
When [`_.inRange`](https://lodash.com/docs#inRange) is used with `end < start`, the values are flipped, so `start = end` and `end = start`. This is undocumented behavior.

IMO, this behavior is incorrect: `_.inRange` should just return `false` when `end < start`. This caused a problem in my code:

``` js
$checkbox.prop({indeterminate: _.inRange(selectedCount, 1, items.length)});
```

title: Feature: throw on undefined properties in _.template
body:
`_.template` will throw if you try to use something like `<%= data.user.email %>` where `data.user` is not defined. It'll fail silently though if the user exists but has no email. It'll just be an empty string. This should fail in my opinion or result in printing 'undefined' as string instead. This would very likely break stuff so the best way to handle this is probably by inserting a opt-in option.

If any of the named ways is a good idea in your opinion I'd also open a PR if you'd want me too.

title: Invalidate cached result of before functions
body:
When I use `_.once` for caching expensive function calls, I would like the possibility to invalidate the cached result at some point. Would this be possible with lodash? When looking into the source code, I did not see any possibility to reset the value of `n` in `function before`.

A trivial workaround would be to replace the existing function with a new `_.once` function.

title: _.compact and holes
body:
> Creates an array with all falsey values removed. The values false, null, 0, "", undefined, and NaN are falsey.

Compact also seems to remove holes.  Undocumented feature, unintentional side effect, or just general policy against returning array with holes?  Should it be documented either way?

```
log(  _.compact( [ 1, , , , 2 ] )  )  //=> [1,2]
```

title: Object treated as an array of undefined values when iterating over an object with floating point values
A way to clone array on purpose when using chain call.
body:
Hello!

In 3.10.0:

```
var arr = [1, 2, 3];

var arr2 = _.chain(arr)
    .slice()
    .reverse()
    .value();

console.log('arr2: ', arr2); // [3, 2, 1]

console.log('arr: ', arr); // [3, 2, 1]

// in 3.9.3 and prior to it 'console.log(arr);' would return [1, 2, 3]. The initial array would be untouched.
```

First i'd like to say, that it is unintuitive, undocumented(nothing in the changelog) and it broke a part of our project. Supposing, that the change was intentional(short fusion), the question is: is there a way to clone an array on purpose, considering that `_.clone` and `_.cloneDeep` aren't chainable?

Thank you!

title: _.includes handles empty arrays as target oddly
Undefined used as weak map key
body:
Hi,

I am using lodash with node.js 0.12.5 and am getting following error thrown.

```
      return metaMap.get(func);
                     ^
TypeError: Invalid value used as weak map key
    at WeakMap.get (native)
    at getData (/home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3856:22)
    at isLaziable (/home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:4142:18)
    at wrapper (/home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3524:17)
    at dropTableStep (/home/bore/stuff/src/event-summary.js:29:12)
    at /home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3337:35
    at arrayMap (/home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:1431:25)
    at Function.map (/home/bore/stuff/node_modules/lodash/index.js:6693:14)
    ....
```

On a first glance it seems strange to use `other` as a lookup key [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/7351c0b0b941e7faa450a7f53713659b3ebe76dc/lodash.js#L4151) as all non-lodash functions will cause it to evaluate to undefined (thus causing the error).

```
[...]

> _.assign
```

Note: the implementation is identical to words and the two functions can be easily share a creator function (I can do that in a subsequent commit if you wish).

title: _.escapeRegExp modifies regular digits
body:
It looks like the changes in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/10c2232c398e095ff52f2306df08f0a0e0350285 broke a simple validator a co-worker built - essentially we were using `_.escapeRegExp` to remove special chars before searching for email addresses and phone numbers. We take the search term and make a RegExp with it, as an easy way to match substrings.

Running the string `"555-5555"` through `_.escapeRegExp` returns `"\x3555-5555"`. Is this desired behaviour? Are we using the method for a purpose not intended?

title: Surprising output from map based on array ordering
body:
I'm kind of stumped:

```
_.map( ['B', 'A'], _.partial(_.startsWith, 'BETA'))
Array [ true, false ] // yes, 'BETA' begins with 'B' but not with 'A'

_.map( ['A', 'B'], _.partial(_.startsWith, 'BETA'))
Array [ false, false ] // wuh?
```

The idea I'm trying to capture is that with a single string ("BETA"), I want to check an array and see if "BETA" begins with any of the strings in that array.  I was using `any` at first, but when it was acting strange, I decided to try `map` instead, to help debug.

What am I missing?

I'm at a crossroad where a good portion of functionality can be solved by lodash, and was wondering what legal/licensing requirements there are if I bundle parts of lodash in the "production" ready Toolkit code, found here: https://github.com/titon/toolkit/tree/3.0/dist

I'm assuming that I would simply have to place the license in the file. If there's anything else let me know. Or if you guys are against this approach as well. Full credit will be given throughout.

title: Support hint param for sortedIndex
body: [As it is now](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L2767), the first index checked is naturally the midpoint of the array. This is a good default but sometimes the programmer knows some information about a likely insertion position for the value. Would be great if lodash supported an additional `hint` param!

title: _.isEqual customizer callback is invoked without the third argument "key"
Only set difference is supported
body:
`_.difference` does set difference, in that it removes all occurrences of the other elements provided.  This is oftentimes (and I would argue usually) not what you want, since you can achieve the current behavior by calling `_.uniq` on the first array, but you can't achieve 'exact difference' in a clean way as is.

e.g. With set difference:

``` javascript
_.difference([1, 1, 2, 3], [1])
Array [ 2, 3 ]
```

'Exact difference' would yield `[1, 2, 3]` here.

`_.without`, etc. suffer from the same issues.

title: `throttled.cancel()` doesn't clear the timeout and cached value
Support native ES6 Iterable protocol [Symbol.iterator]
body:
This would be a pretty nice stepping stone into ES6 compatibility. Reverse of #737.

I'm not too familiar with the code but here's my high level take:
- Define only if `Symbol.iterator` is defined
- `lodash.prototype[Symbol.iterator]` returns a stateful object with i=0
- `next()` will return `{ value: at(i++), done: false }` or `{ value: null, done: true }`

I'm willing to implement this if you feel like this would be a useful addition.

I can submit a pull request if you are interested.

title: Use push() in arrayFilter() rather than assignment by index.
body:
As explained in #1287.

Tests are passing.

title: Performance of arrayFilter
body:
While reading the source of the `arrayFilter()` method, I noticed how you're tracking the `resIndex` yourself and then assigning the elements in the result array by index. This made me think, why not simply use the `Array.prototype.push()` method? I figured the answer might be in the performance, so I created a jsperf to compare the two variations: http://jsperf.com/assign-by-index-vs-push

I ran the results on Chrome 43, Firefox 37, Safari 8 and IE 11*. The results are that using `push()` is slightly faster on Chrome, slightly slower on Safari and about equal on IE. The outlier is Firefox for which using `push()` is more than twice as fast.

For this reason I'd say it's better to use `push()` in the `arrayFilter()` method.

Finally, checking the source for `baseFilter()` I see you're using `push()` there as well. So just for consistency's sake I'd also say `push()` is the way to go.

*) IE11 is reported by jsperf as "Other", maybe because I was running it inside a VM.


Is this a bug or did I use it wrong?

While checking out lodash-migrate I noticed that `_.memoize.Cache` was dropped because:

``` js
_.memoize = _.wrap(_.memoize, function () {
  ...
})
```

I am of the opinion that `_.wrap` should assign all of the own properties of the value to the result, but this is quite a bit slower: http://jsperf.com/assign-after-wrap

What do you think?

title: Inconsistency: chaining zipWith
body:
I am unsure if this is by design or not, but it took me by surprise so I thought I'll post it here:

`zipWith` is listed as a chainable method in the docs, but since `_(value)` only takes one value, you can't really start a chain with `zipWith`. I guess this goes for `zip` as well, or any other function that needs two or more input values for that matter.

Fake edit: after testing a bit more, I found that I can start a chain with `zipWith` if I write it like this:
`_(value).zipWith(secondValue, fn)`. It actually makes sense to do it like this, I'll admit that, but it still took me a while to figure it out. Might I suggest pointing out this "peculiarity" in the docs? :)

title: bindAll doesn't work with chaining
body:
The [docs](https://lodash.com/docs#_) state that bindAll is a chainable method, and I think it was at some point in time. However, this doesn't appear to be the case anymore. The following code:

```
var _ = require('lodash')

var A = function (val) {
    this.val = val
    _(this).bindAll('chained')
    _.bindAll(this, 'notchained')
}

A.prototype.chained = function () {
    return this.val
}

A.prototype.notchained = function () {
    return this.val
}

var a = new A('engage!')

console.log('a.chained(): ', a.chained())
console.log('a.notchained(): ', a.notchained())

console.log('a.chained.call(): ', a.chained.call())
console.log('a.notchained.call(): ', a.notchained.call())
```

Produces the following output:

```
a.chained():  engage!
a.notchained():  engage!
a.chained.call():  undefined
a.notchained.call():  engage!
```

 `_.bindAll(this, 'notchained')` is working as expected, but `_.bindAll(this, 'notchained')` is not.

title: _.ary can create wrappers with exact arity.
body:
This pull request allows `_.ary` to take an extra argument, which when true, creates a wrapper function that has the exact right arity.

``` js
_.ary(fn, 5).length === 5
```

There's are a couple of JS libraries where function arity is important (Express, for instance).

title: Reverse Deep Merge

_.trimRight not working as docs explain.
body:
From the docs

> `_.trimRight([string=''], [chars=whitespace])`
> 
> Removes trailing whitespace or specified characters from string.
> 
> Arguments
> [string=''](string): The string to trim.
> [chars=whitespace](string): The characters to trim.
> Returns
> (string): Returns the trimmed string.

So when I run `_.trimRight('foo-bar.baz', '.baz');`
I expect `foo-bar` to be returned. However, I only receive 'foo'

When I run `_.trimRight('foo-bar.baz');`
I expect `foo-bar.baz` to be returned. However, I only receive 'foo'

Node: v0.12.3
Npm: v2.9.1
lodash: v3.9.3
